%md
# About
**Lab:** Exploring Query Execution
**Objective:** Explore how Spark executes RDD and DataFrame/Dataset queries.
**File locations:**
    HDFS: /user/zeppelin/hive/telco.db/accounts
          /user/zeppelin/weblogs
          /user/zeppelin/devices.json
          /user/zeppelin/accountdevice
    Hive tables: telco.accounts
**Successful outcome:** 
**Before you begin:** 
**Related lessons:** 

---

%md
# Setup

msg.data:
Setup

Important: This exercise depends on ***Insert previous exercise title here (with link?)*** . If you did not complete that exercise, run the course catch-up script and advance to the current exercise:

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Explore Partitioning of File-Based RDDs

msg.data: Explore Partitioning of File-Based RDDs

paragraphs.title: 1 - Note the number and size of accounts data files in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
Review the accounts data files in HDFS. (`user/zeppelin/accounts`) Take note of the number and sizes of files.

%sh
hdfs dfs -ls /user/zeppelin/hive/telco.db/accounts

msg.data:
Found 13 items
drwx------   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-21 12:02 /user/zeppelin/.Trash
drwxr-xr-x   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-21 17:42 /user/zeppelin/.sparkStaging
drwxr-xr-x   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-21 20:36 /user/zeppelin/accountdevice
drwxr-xr-x   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-22 20:49 /user/zeppelin/accounts_zip94913

-rw-r--r--   3 zeppelin hdfs       5483 2020-05-21 18:32 /user/zeppelin/devices.json

drwxr-xr-x   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-22 01:49 /user/zeppelin/weblogs

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create an RDD using the accounts data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create an RDD called `accountsRDD` by reading the accounts data, splitting it by commas, and keying it by account ID, which is the first field of each line.

%spark2
val accountsRDD = sc.
textFile("/user/zeppelin/hive/telco.db/accounts").
map(line => line.split(',')).
map(account => (account(0),account))

paragraphs.title: 3 - Find the number of partitions in the new RDD
paragraphs.text:
%spark2
accountsRDD.getNumPartitions

paragraphs.title: 4 - Review the lineage and execution plan of accountsRDD
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use `toDebugString` to view the lineage and execution plan of `accountsRDD`. How many partitions are in the resulting RDD? How may stages does the query have?

%spark2
accountsRDD.toDebugString

%md
### Explore Execution of RDD Queries

msg.data: Explore Execution of RDD Queries

paragraphs.title: 5 - Trigger the execution of a job
paragraphs.text:
%md
Call `count` on `accountsRDD` to count the number of accounts. This will trigger execution of a job.
%spark2

paragraphs.title: 6 - View the Spark application UI
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the browser, view the application in the YARN RM UI and click through to view the Spark Application UI.

msg.data:
In the browser, view the application in the YARN RM UI using the provided bookmark (or http://localhost:8088 and click through to view the Spark Application UI.

!!!! Does this link work? !!!

paragraphs.title: 7 - Confirm that the execution of the job matches the results from toDebugString
paragraphs.text:
%md
Make sure the **Jobs** tab is selected, and review the list of completed jobs. The most recent job, which you triggered by calling count, should be at the top of the list. (Note that the job description is usually based on the action that triggered the job execution.) Confirm that the number of stages is correct, and the number of tasks completed for the job matches the number of RDD partitions you noted when you used `toDebugString`.

paragraphs.title: 8 - View the details of the job
paragraphs.text:
%md
Click on the job description to view details of the job. This will list all the stages in the job, which in this case is one.

paragraphs.title: 9 - View the diagram of the execution plan
paragraphs.text:
%md
Click on **DAG Visualization** to see a diagram of the execution plan based on the RDD's lineage. The main diagram displays only the stages, but if you click on a stage, it will show you the tasks within that stage.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Explore the partitioning and DAG of a more complex query
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* Explore the partitioning and DAG of a more complex query like the one below. Before you view the execution plan or job details, try to figure out how many stages the job will have.

This query loads Loudacre's web log data, and calculates how many times each user visited. Then it joins that user count data with account data for each user.

%spark2
val logs = sc.textFile("/user/zeppelin/weblogs")

val userReqsRDD = logs.map(line => line.split(' ')).
map(words => (words(2),1)).
reduceByKey((v1,v2) => v1 + v2)

val accountHitsRDD = accountsRDD.join(userReqsRDD)
accountHitsRDD.saveAsTextFile("/user/zeppelin/account_hits")

%md
**Note:** If you execute the query multiple times, you may note that some tasks within a stage are marked as "skipped."" This is because whenever a shuffle operation is executed, Spark temporarily caches the data that was shuffled. Subsequent executions of the same query re-use that data if it's available to save some steps and improve performance.

msg.data:
Note: If you execute the query multiple times, you may note that some tasks within
a stage are marked as “skipped.“” This is because whenever a shuffle operation
is executed, Spark temporarily caches the data that was shuffled. Subsequent
executions of the same query re-use that data if it's available to save some steps and
improve performance.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Explore Execution of DataFrame Queries

msg.data: Explore Execution of DataFrame Queries

paragraphs.title: 11 - Create a DataFrame of active accounts
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a DataFrame of active accounts from the `accounts` table in the `telco` database.

%spark2
val accountsDF = spark.read.table("telco.accounts")

val activeAccountsDF = accountsDF.
select("acct_num").
where($"acct_close_dt".isNull)

paragraphs.title: 12 - View the full execution plan for the new DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%spark2
activeAccountsDF.explain(true)

%md
Can you locate the line in the physical plan corresponding to the command to load the `telco.accounts` table into a DataFrame?

How many stages do you think this query has?

msg.data:
Can you locate the line in the physical plan corresponding to the command to load
the devsh.accounts table into a DataFrame?

How many stages do you think this query has?

paragraphs.title: 13 - Call the DataFrame's show function to execute the query
paragraphs.text: %spark2

paragraphs.title: 14 - Use the Spark Application UI to view the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
View the Spark Application UI and choose the **SQL** tab. This displays a list of DataFrame and Dataset queries you have executed, with the most recent query at the top.

paragraphs.title: 15 - View the query's execution plan
paragraphs.text:
%md
Click the description for the top query to see the visualization of the query's execution. You can also see the query's full execution plan by opening the **Details** panel below the visualization graph.

paragraphs.title: 16 - Review the query's execution plan
paragraphs.text:
%md
The first step in the execution is a `HiveTableScan`, which loaded the account data into the DataFrame. Hover your mouse over the step to show the step's execution plan. Compare that to the physical plan for the query. Note that it is the same as the last line in the physical execution plan, because it is the first step to execute. Did you correctly identify this line in the execution plan as the one corresponding to the `DataFrame.read.table` operation?

paragraphs.title: 17 - View the job details for the query
paragraphs.text:
%md
Click the **SQL** tab to return to the main SQL query summary tab. The **Job IDs** column provides links to the jobs that executed as part of this query execution. In this case, the query consisted of just a single job. Click the job's ID to view the job details. This will display a list of stages that were completed for the query. How many stages executed? Is that the number of stages you predicted it would be?

paragraphs.title: 18 - View metrics of the execution
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* Click the description of the stage to view metrics on the execution of the stage and its tasks.

paragraphs.title: 19 - Joining different data sources
paragraphs.text:
%md
The previous query was very simple, involving just a single data source with a where to return only active accounts. Try executing a more complex query that joins data from two different data sources.

This query reads in the `accountdevice` data file, which maps account IDs to associated device IDs. Then it joins that data with the DataFrame of active accounts you created above. The result is DataFrame consisting of all device IDs in use by currently active accounts.

msg.data:
The previous query was very simple, involving just a single data source with a
where to return only active accounts. Try executing a more complex query that
joins data from two different data sources.

This query reads in the accountdevice data file, which maps account IDs to
associated device IDs. Then it joins that data with the DataFrame of active accounts
you created above. The result is DataFrame consisting of all device IDs in use by
currently active accounts.

paragraphs.text:
%spark2
val accountDeviceDF = spark.read.
option("header","true").
option("inferSchema","true").
csv("/user/zeppelin/accountdevice")

val activeAcctDevsDF = activeAccountsDF.
join(accountDeviceDF,$"acct_num" === $"account_id").
select($"device_id")

paragraphs.title: 20 - Analyzing the execution plan
paragraphs.text:
%md
Review the full execution plan using `explain`, as you did with the previous DataFrame.

Can you identify which lines in the execution plan load the two different data sources?

How many stages do you think this query will execute?

msg.data:
Review the full execution plan using explain, as you did with the previous
DataFrame.

Can you identify which lines in the execution plan load the two different data
sources?

How many stages do you think this query will execute?

paragraphs.text: %spark2

paragraphs.title: 21 - Analyzing the execution visualization
paragraphs.text:
%md
Execute the query and review the execution visualization in the Spark UI.

What differences do you see between the execution of the earlier query and this one?

How many stages executed? Is this what you expected?

msg.data:
Execute the query and review the execution visualization in the Spark UI.

What differences do you see between the execution of the earlier query and this
one?

How many stages executed? Is this what you expected?

paragraphs.text: %spark2

paragraphs.title: 22 - Explore a query with multiple joins
paragraphs.text:
%md
*Optional:* Explore an even more complex query that involves multiple joins with three data sources. You can use the last query in the solutions file for this exercise (in the `/home/devuser/bin/devsh/exercises/query-execution/solution/ directory`). That query creates a list of device IDs, makes, and models, and the number of active accounts that use that type of device, sorted in order from most popular device type to least.

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
